prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for having an Almanac?
A bit of backstory. I met my wife in the summer of 2008. She was working as the ice cream girl at a local restaurant. I had gone to pick up some boxes because I was moving. Out walked my Sara...it was close to the end of her shift. And working in this particular restaurant was a...dirty job to say the least. (Seriously, I don't care what DDD says, that place is gross.) She was covered in sweat from cleaning the machines, caked in all the dirt from that nasty little kitchen, had a grease stain on her cheek...and she was fucking beautiful. Her smile, her easy laugh, her obvious intelligence...I'm pretty sure I fell in love right then and there that wonderful May night. (inb4 "tHAts sO OlD faShIOned!!!" Don't care. When you know, you know.) I wasted no time in asking her out and we hit it off immediately.
It started after our first date. She had mentioned she loves lilacs. Me, being a 23 year old guy at the time, didn't know Jack or shit about flowers. But the way she talked about how much she loved them I knew I didn't want to forget that tidbit of information. So I wrote it down in one of those mini spiral notebooks. (Think what cops use to take notes.) This was The Almanacs genesis. Over the years I've written down information about my wife. Her favorite color, her favorite restaurants, her favorite books, movies she wants to see, etc. Basically all the little things I knew I would forget. Anything that struck me as worthy of remembering when she told me. I would go through it every once in a while so I could do something sweet for her. Fast forward to yesterday morning.
I get a call from her around 11am. "What the fuck is The Almanac?" (The Almanac is written on the cover. It's just a silly name that occurred to me a few years ago.) She obviously has it, and I don't lie to my wife, so I tell her. She gets really quiet for maybe half a minute and then says "I always thought you remembered this stuff..." tells me she has to run and hangs up. I get home from work last night and she's really dejected. I asked her what's wrong and she says the Almanac has cheapened every sweet thing I've ever done for her. She called it my "playbook" and said she felt betrayed. Mind you I've never showed it to a single soul nor have I even told anyone about it. Until yesterday I was the only person in the world to know of it's existence. (She also said she hasn't decided if I can have it back or not, and that she's thinking about destroying it.) I'm kind of heart broken. I feel like this should be an example of how much I love her. I'm terrified she's going to burn it. I WANT to remember all these details that make my wife who she is. That's why I write them down. I don't chronicle these things for brownie points or status. I do it because I love my wife. I hear so many wives bitch that their husbands don't remember shit, and I don't want to be that guy. So yeah, I took notes. And now I'm getting the silent treatment. Or at best single word answers.
AITA here?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. So the user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for keeping an almanac of notes about his wife. The author created this notebook to remember personal details about his wife, like her favorite things and interests, to make sure he could do sweet things for her. But his wife found out and is now upset, feeling that the almanac has cheapened his gestures and made her feel like he's using a playbook, leading to betrayal.

First, I need to consider both sides. The author's intention was good—he wanted to show his love by remembering important things about her. Keeping a list of her preferences seems like a thoughtful way to personalize his actions. However, the wife's reaction is significant here. She feels that the almanac has reduced the authenticity of his gestures. Maybe she values spontaneous actions more than planned ones based on a list. She might feel that her personal information should be kept private, and the fact that he's written it down feels intrusive or like a tool for manipulation, even if that's not the case.

The key points here are consent and perception. The author didn't tell her about the almanac, so she didn't know it existed until he was forced to explain. Even though his intentions were good, he kept something private without her awareness. The wife might see this as a breach of trust because she didn't know he was keeping track of her personal details. Even if he didn't mean to, the act of keeping a "playbook" could make her feel that her personal information is being used, which she didn't agree to. 

Another angle is the concept of privacy within a relationship. While sharing personal information is common in relationships, keeping a detailed record without the other person's knowledge might cross a line. The wife's reaction suggests that she values the spontaneity and sincerity in gestures, and the existence of the almanac made her feel that those gestures were insincere, as if they were part of a script. That's a valid feeling for her, even if the author didn't intend it that way.

On the other hand, the author argues that the almanac is a way for him to remember things he otherwise might forget, especially since he's not naturally good at remembering such details. He's trying to be a thoughtful partner. However, the problem arises from the fact that he didn't communicate this with her. If he had discussed his intentions with her and asked if it was okay, maybe she would have had a different reaction. But since he kept it a secret, her discovery of it leads to hurt feelings.

In relationships, communication is key. The author might not have realized that his actions, while well-intentioned, could be perceived as manipulative or intrusive. The wife's feelings of betrayal and being played are valid because she wasn't part of the decision-making process regarding her personal information. Even though he didn't share it with others, the act of keeping a private record without her knowledge is problematic.

So, considering all these factors, the author might indeed be in the wrong. The issue isn't the act of writing things down per se, but the lack of transparency and the resulting negative impact on the wife's feelings. The author should reflect on whether the method he used to show his love aligns with his wife's expectations and their communication about such matters.
